data.title: Generate API documentation with TypeDoc
data.body:
This PR should resolve #668 

This generates a multi-page API site from the d.ts files.  It also updates the comment parser to be able to handle multi-line formal comment extraction in case there is a need for more verbose documentation of API methods.

```
/**
This is a formal comment
*/
```

I'm unsure if this will work correctly with the CI builds, so I'm going to need some help with that.

data.title: Combined d.ts file is not working on windows builds
Added SetSubimage to copy contents of an image to a rect in another image
data.body: Added this as part of the lightmapping work, but someone on gitter was looking for this functionality specifically so decided to PR separately.

data.title: Work on migrating native editor events to Typescript + ResourceEditor instantiation refactor
data.body:
This PR migrates some of the events that were on the native side into the typescript side.  Namely ProjectUnloaded and DeleteResource.  Unfortunately, the HandleWebMessage event can't be migrated yet because there is no way for the Typescript to handle the E_WEBVIEWMESSAGE.HANDLER->Success() message, so the engine throws an error that the message has been unhandled.

This also refactors the way editors are instantiated by having an Editor Builder service that editor builders can register with.  The ResourceFrame then passes a path to this service and is returned a builder for that type of editor.  Each builder is also in charge of hooking in and responding to the appropriate events for that editor.  This could probably be expanded in the future to allow user provided editors and also migrate more out of the ResourceFrame.ts, but it's a start.

data.title: [Prefabs 2.0] Changes to objects based on prefabs are lost when saving/loading a scene

milestone.title: Issue Staging
milestone.description: A staging area for milestones, while we work through the backlog

data.body:
Repro:
*Create an empty scene
*Create a simple object with a StaticModel component
*Make a prefab of that object
*Drag a prefab version into a scene
*Change a simple value like LOD Bias on both the original and prefab copy objects, do NOT apply changes back to the prefab
*Save the scene
*Close and reopen the scene. Note the changes on the non-prefab object persist, but not on the preab copy object

data.title: User preferences system for extensions
data.body:
This PR adds the ability for host extensions to store and retrieve preferences from the project user preferences file.  These preferences are also propagated to the web client so that editor extensions can retrieve the settings.  Additionally, whenever preferences are changed from the host, a preference change event is sent to the web client so the web client can respond appropriately.

The other changes here are some lint whitespace changes and also refactoring of the webview client extension names and structure to more closely match the changes made the host extension naming done in a previous PR.

I did have a question on the user preference file.  I'm using: 

```
ToolCore.toolSystem.project.userPrefsFullPath 
```

to store the preferences in and this points to a file called `projectname.userpreferences`.  It appears that the Snap Settings dialog stores settings in a different file called `UserPrefs.json` .  Should't those also be stored in the `projectname.userpreferences` file?  

I updated the routine that saves the Snap Settings to not overwrite the file, but to retain any extraneous settings that may also be in there and just update with the known settings, so switching over to the `projectname.userpreferences` file should be seamless if that's the way you would like to go.  Either that or have `ToolCore.toolsSystem.project.userPrefsFullPath` point to the `UserPrefs.json` file.

I'm going to be using this to coordinate some settings in the TypeScript extension, but thought I would break out just the user settings piece into it's own PR so it's easier to digest.

data.title: Add ability to set zoom level on webview + less sleep for IPC on Windows
Make a pass at generating all temporary files in Artifacts
data.body:
I'm thinking temporary files should be generated under Artifacts, this way when doing a non-Dev Build everything will be built/generated/copied in the Artifacts folder and not the source tree.

"Dev Builds" run from the resources/data in the source tree, which is really helpful while developing.  This fact complicates keeping the source tree clean, wrt generated files.  We probably do have to copy required files into the source tree for the time being

data.title: Exposing a few properties that are great for tweening on UIWidget.
Combine d.ts files
data.body:
This PR adds an extra build step that will combine all of the generated d.ts files into a single Atomic.d.ts and place it under Script/TypeScript/dist and also placed in the distribution under Data/AtomicEditor/TypeScriptSupport.

A new dependency was brought in to accomplish this: https://github.com/SitePen/dts-generator which is under the New BSD, so if that's not compatible then I'll determine another way to do this.

This closes #764

data.title: evaluate/add hjson file support to complement json
data.body:
http://hjson.org/

hjson format could help when editing configuration files, project data files, etc.  It allows comments, multiline strings, and is less error prone when hand editing.  It converts to JSON which can then be consumed by JS or native C++ code

data.title: #623 windows texture compression
Be able to upgrade core resources in an existing project on editor upgrades
data.body:
Based upon discussions with both @mattbenic  and @JoshEngebretson, it seems that there should be a way to upgrade current resources in a project when a new version of the editor drops.  One main culprit of this is to be able to bring in the latest *.d.ts files on each new update.  I'm thinking that this could be delegated to the extension subsystem.  What I'm thinking is that the editor can execute a method on the extension ServiceLocator:

```
ServiceLocator.upgradeHandler.isUpgradeAvailable({editor version});
```

If any extensions subscribed to this event return `true` then either an upgrade menu item appears or a dialog box pops up stating : "Project Upgrades Available.  Do you want to apply them?"

If the answer is yes, then the editor calls

```
ServiceLocator.upgradeHandler.applyUpgrades
```

And then it is up to each extension to upgrade the relevant files as necessary.  For instance the TypeScript extension could have the latest _.d.ts files somewhere and it could overwrite the files in ```ProjectRoot/typings/Atomic/_```

data.title: Refactoring the extension interface names to make more sense
data.body:
This PR attempts to make the extension interfaces make more sense.  The concept is that you have ServiceProviders that provide functionality that an extension can request, and ServiceListeners which the extension implements so that it can respond to service events coming from the editor.

The following name changes were made:

```
ServiceRegistry<T> -> ServicesProvider<T>
ProjectServiceRegistry -> ProjectServicesProvider
ResourceServiceRegistry -> ResourceServicesProvider
UIServiceRegistry -> UIServicesProvider
ProjectService -> ProjectServicesEventListener
ResourceService -> ResourceServicesEventListener
UIService -> UIServicesEventListener
```

This now changes the way to implement an extension from:

```
export default class Extension implements Editor.HostExtensions.ResourceService, Editor.HostExtensions.ProjectService
```

to

```
export default class Extension implements Editor.HostExtensions.ResourceServicesEventListener, Editor.HostExtensions.ProjectServicesEventListener 
```
